lang: en | fa | es | zh-Hant | zh-Hans | th | hr | ro | ar | pt-BR | sr | hu | fr | ja | sq | vi | pt | id | tr | ru
speaker: Hugo Mercier

title: Did ancient Troy really exist?
description: When Homer's Iliad was first written down in the eighth century BCE, the story of the Trojan war was already an old one. From existing oral tradition, audiences knew the tales of the long siege, the duels outside the city walls, and the trick that finally won the war. In the end, the city was burned to the ground, never to rise again. But had it ever existed? Einav Zamir Dembin investigates. [TED-Ed Animation by Cabong Studios]
keywords: TED-Ed, ancient world, archaeology, history
lang: en | pt | es | tr | vi | fa | fr | th | zh-Hans | ar | zh-Hant | ru | el | ko | pt-BR | it | bg | sr | pl | ja
speaker: Einav Zamir Dembin

title: Don't quit your job, use it for good
description: When the 2010 earthquake hit Haiti, Viviana Alvarez was sitting at her desk in the UK. Immediately, she wanted to quit her job and help — but she didn't. Instead, she leveraged her job to make the greatest difference she could make.
keywords: disaster relief, environment, development
speaker: Viviana Alvarez
speaker_about: In addition to her position as Global Customer Service Manager, Viviana Alvarez is a Unilever Global Foundation Ambassador and the President and co-founder of an NGO called Help to Haiti (H2H). In 2010, she was driven to help the people of Haiti after the devastating earthquake that struck. H2H remains focused on delivering basic needs, infrastructure, education, health and micro-financing to Haitian families.

title: How can we give our kids a brighter future?
description: Strap video cameras to their foreheads! To better understand child development, Richard Neville decided to see the world from a child's point of view. What did he observe? Children want to learn, and we might just be getting in their way...
keywords: children, brain, education
speaker: Richard Neville
speaker_about: In a world in which corporate entities can be as influential as governments, Richard Neville is convinced that consumers will prefer to support brands that put good things in the world. His agency Animl works with Unilever’s Dirt Is Good brands to understand the changing nature of childhood in the 21st century.

title: Watch what you dispose of
description: Rania Bahaa is talking trash, literally. In an effort to send zero waste to landfills, she presents innovative approaches her company has developed. (One example: plastic straps as prayer mats.)
keywords: sustainability, development, environment
speaker: Rania Bahaa
speaker_about: Rania Bahaa is an Environmental Specialist at Unilever Mashreq in Egypt. Bahaa has led several innovative programs, across four Unilever factories, to meet the challenge that Unilever factories should create zero waste to landfill. This included the Waraqa Center, a program that created economic opportunities for local community members who re-craft food and packaging by-products into second lives as new products that they sell. The Waraqa Centre and communication around it is helping to shift the local and Egyptian community perspective on sustainability.

title: Why we hire "unemployable" people
description: Trips to a bakery always ends with a cookie and a smile — but at the bakery run by Mike Brady and Dion Drew, the extra icing is their goal of serving up a second chance. The recipe for the success of their enterprise includes a commitment to employing a range of chronically unemployed people, including former convicts and recovering addicts.
keywords: society, work, success
speaker: Mike Brady and Dion Drew
speaker_about: By building on the Greyston Bakery’s thirty-year heritage as a model for social enterprise using entrepreneurship to address the issues of generational poverty, President and CEO Mike Brady serves Yonkers, NY as a force for personal transformation and community economic renewal. Greyston is best known for a 24- year relationship of baking brownies for Ben and Jerry’s ice cream. Mike’s passion for social entrepreneurism and the use of business to solve social issues are fundamental to his work at Greyston Bakery.

title: A personal story about farming and the future of agriculture
description: In 1890, Mark Jackson's great-great-great-grandfather bought a plot of land in southern Iowa. Five generations later, Mark is still farming that same land but using some very different techniques. In this moving story that crosses generations, Mark shows us both how radically agriculture has changed since that time, and the ways some things have stayed exactly the same.
keywords: agriculture, farming, technology
speaker: Mark Jackson
speaker_about: Mark Jackson is CEO of Jackson Farms LS, Inc and currently serves as a National Director of the American Soybean Association. He is a fifth generation Iowa farmer who practices sustainable production and environmental responsibility in his modern family farming operations. He was one of the original farmers who pioneered sustainable soybean farming with Unilever.

title: The power of transformative collaboration
description: Climate change is a global issue and action must come from every aspect of society to yield the needed change. How can corporations make a difference without losing profit? Keith Weed argues that sustainability and economic growth can go hand-in-hand, after implementing a few key approaches.
keywords: economics, sustainability, climate change
speaker: Keith Weed
speaker_about: As Chief Marketing and Communications Officer at Unilever, Keith Weed sees sustainability as a driver of consumer-led profitable growth. Along with the leading the creation of the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan, he has also pioneered new ways of integrating sustainability into the business. Weed has led a step change in marketing at Unilever, most notably with significant advances in digital marketing and technologies, and has championed the development of brands with purpose through Unilever’s crafting Brands for Life strategy.

title: Solving the sanitation crisis
description: The lack of private and fully functioning toilets threatens the health and welfare of too many people. John Kluge, co-founder of Toilet Hackers, explains that access to toilets affects everything from education to the economy, and offers some workable solutions to address the crisis.
keywords: water, sanitation, development
speaker: John Kluge Jr.
speaker_about: John Kluge Jr. is an entrepreneur who started for-profit angel investment firm, Eirene, to support issues that will impact at least one billion people. He also co-founded Toilet Hackers, a non-profit organization committed to raising awareness and providing access to dignified sanitation to the 2.5 billion people without a toilet. Kluge espouses a PhilanthroPunk philosophy -- punk rock attitude applied to philanthropy at a mass scale.

title: Feeding the future
description: By 2050, global food production must double to keep up with population growth. How does the man "who buys the most food in America" think this can be accomplished? Jack Sinclair, Executive Vice President of the Walmart US Grocery division, shares a few ideas on what we can do to produce more, sustainability. (One of them: re-use the apples in America that weren't good enough to eat, to make juice.)
keywords: sustainability, food, population
speaker: Jack Sinclair
speaker_about: Introducing “the man that buys the most food in America,” Jack Sinclair is the executive vice president of the Walmart US Grocery Division and is responsible for all aspects of the merchandise grocery business at Walmart’s stores in the US. Sinclair joined Walmart in 2007 from McCurrach, a U.K.-based field merchandising business. He has also previously worked for Tesco and Safeway PLC, where he eventually served on the board of directors that led the merger of Safeway PLC and Morrisons.

title: Owning the kitchen again
description: For many parents, 4:30 pm is crunch-time. Kids are running amok and the pressure is on to make a dinner that will satisfy the whole family. Through her own personal story, Einav Gefen, corporate Chef of Unilever, explains what we can do to make 4:30 a little less challenging and why convenience is not a dirty word.
keywords: family, food, health
speaker: Einav Gefen
speaker_about: Einav is the lead Corporate Chef at Unilever’s North America’s kitchens. Her role is to bring culinary insights to both products and recipes as well as help the American home cook put a tasty meal on the table. She uses her Chef’s hat to lend credibility to products that can be an easy solution to creating home cooked meals and building sustainable culinary solution to the question “What’s for dinner tonight”? Gefen graduated and taught at the Institute of Culinary Education in NYC.

title: When will I get my water next?
description: Three billion people in the world don't have access to a consistent water supply, due to issues not limited to infrastructure, supply or mismanagement — and for some, water may flow every two days or even ten. Sustainability engineer Anu Sridharan launched an organization in India that wants to fix this using cellphones and the power of crowdsourcing information.
keywords: sustainability, water, india
speaker: Anu Sridharan
speaker_about: A former civil engineering student, Anu Sridharan is passionate about improving access and health for communities in urban India. She is the cofounder of "Next Drop," a service that sends text message alerts to at least 75,000 residents in Hubli-Dharwad, India to notify them with the date and time a fresh supply of water is due to be piped to their area.

title: The Big Pivot
description: Warning signs of advancing climate change abound. Extreme weather, scarcity, and the rising cost of commodities foreshadow what might be ahead. Can we alter this perilous trajectory? Andrew Winston thinks we can, but to do so we must fundamentally shift the way business functions.
keywords: climate change, business, environment
speaker: Andrew Winston
speaker_about: Andrew Winston is a globally recognized expert on how companies can navigate and profit from humanity’s biggest challenges. His views on strategy have been sought after by many of the world’s leading companies, including Boeing, HP, Kimberly-Clark, PepsiCo, and Unilever. Winston’s book The Big Pivot lays out a practical and optimistic roadmap for how companies can thrive in a hotter, scarcer, more open world.

title: Let them be scientists
description: The key to inspiring children to pursue science can be found in the curious and inquisitive spirit we all tap into as we first discover the world. Wendy Hawkins demonstrates why we need to inject a more experimental approach into our science curriculum to ensure that we stay connected to the scientist in all of us.
keywords: science, education, teaching
speaker: Wendy Hawkins
speaker_about: Wendy Hawkins is the executive director of the Intel Foundation, which awards grantsfor projects focusing on STEM education (science, technology, engineering and mathematics). In addition, the foundation seeks to increase opportunities for girls, women and under-represented minorities around the globe.

title: The listening bias
description: Listening to both customers and colleagues to gather insights and information is a key ability that successful people possess. Tony Salvador shares some strategies for being a better listener: to lose preconceptions, be vulnerable and open to new ideas, and to not be afraid to hear what we'd rather not hear.
keywords: business, success, communication
speaker: Tony Salvador
speaker_about: In his role as senior principal engineer at Intel, Tony Salvador directs research in the experience Insights Lab within Intel Corporation. He leads a team of social scientists and business analysts to look for, find and develop viable opportunities to create local, sustainable value with new high tech products, services and infrastructures.

title: Training teachers: 10 million and counting
description: The Intel Teach program has trained over 10 million teachers who have transferred these skills to 300 million kids in over 70 countries. Shelley Shott charts the impact of this program, sharing inspiring stories of technology empowering both teachers and students to both create opportunity and benefit their communities.
keywords: teaching, education, technology
speaker: Shelley Shott
speaker_about: As a former middle school teacher and current university lecturer, Shelley Shott takes her knowledge of the educational system to drive development and strategy for K12 education globally at Intel. Her understanding of the impact quality teacher professional development can have on the next generation pushes her passion for working with teachers and education leaders worldwide to help transform classrooms to a student-centric model that prepares kids to be successful in the 21st century.

title: Designing materials one atom at a time
description: The elements in the periodic table were created over billions of years and are rarely supplemented with new elements. Not for long. Sadasivan Shankar reveals that thanks to increasing computing power researchers are designing entirely new materials, one atom at a time, to have the specific properties needed for an infinite number of applications.
keywords: computers, science, technology
speaker: Sadasivan Shankar
speaker_about: Marathon runner and voracious reader, Sadasivan Shankar is the program leader for materialsdesign in Design and Technology Solutions within TMG. Using quantum and atomic techniques, Shankar and his team work closely with the process engineers in designing new materials with targeted functionalities for nanotechnologies. He has co-invented over 20 patent fillings and co-authored atleast 100 external publications, presentations and lectures.

title: Plucky rebels: Being agile in an un-agile place
description: Is it possible for a disruptive and potentially game-changing start-up to take root inside a giant corporation? Peter Biddle draws on his own experience going rogue inside Intel, sharing tips on setting the tone, maintaining secrecy, and communicating discoveries to the mothership.
keywords: business, innovation, communication
speaker: Peter Biddle
speaker_about: As general manager of Cloud Services Platform at Intel Corporation, Peter Biddle is a product development expert in bringing software products from idea to reality. Prior to Intel, he ran all product development and engineering efforts at Trampoline Systems and worked at Microsoft Corporation where he founded the company’s Hypervisor team. His Microsoft team also built BitLocker, a key enterprise-focused feature in Windows Vista and Windows 7.

title: Sound and sentiment
description: What does happiness sound like? What about misery? Musician Mira Calix explores the emotional qualities embedded in music and noise and shares a sound-based spectrum of human sentiments that emerged from her work.
keywords: happiness, emotions, technology
speaker: Mira Calix
speaker_about: Award winning, UK-based composer, artist and performer Mira Calix incorporates her electronic style with classical orchestration into her work for installation pieces, film soundtracks, theatre and opera. Calix is a regular contributor to Intel’s Creators Project which focuses on advancing the research within Intel Labs on emotional connectedness through technology and media.

title: Are you technically fit to parent?
description: Hidden behind the allure of the newest innovations on the web are plenty of potential pitfalls for children—from online bullying to inappropriate content. Michael Fey offers practical advice for parents to close the digital divide between them and their children to help ensure the whole family has a healthy interaction discovering and enjoying the latest technologies.
keywords: parenting, family, technology
speaker: Michael Fey
speaker_about: Worldwide Chief Technology Officer for McAfee and co-author of "Security Battleground: An Executive Field Manual," Michael Fey seeks to drive the company’s long-term strategic vision and core innovation efforts. The book, published in 2012, provides guidance to executives who shoulder oversight responsibility for information security around critical business resources. As a CTO, he is responsible for overseeing McAfee’s go-to-market initiatives, collaboration and execution across McAfee’s sales, product management, development and research terms.

title: The new sharing of emotions
description: Can a smartphone add a new dimension to fostering mental health? Margaret Morris reveals how subjects successfully interacted with their phones throughout the day — mapping moods, charting physical responses and getting instant ideas on confronting situations — and rather than expressing concerns about privacy, they wanted to share their emotions with others.
keywords: emotions, technology, mental health
speaker: Margaret Morris
speaker_about: Clinical psychologist and senior research scientist at Intel, Margaret Morris strives to make technologies that are emotionally helpful. At Intel, she works closely with engineers and designers to promote emotional connectedness and personal change via social media, mobile phones and embedded sensing.

title: How to activate ideas
description: Great incubators of innovations are not limited to garages in Silicon Valley. Manov Subodh charts three principles for sparking entrepreneurial ventures and ideas in people around the world. From dreaming big to getting over the fear of failure, he offers case studies that guide us through the whole process.
keywords: entrepreneur, innovation, failure
speaker: Manav Subodh
speaker_about: Manav Subodh is the global manager for entrepreneurship and innovation in Intel’s Corporate Affairs group. His mission is to collaborate with young innovators, inventors, designers and technology startups in more than 30 countries and provide them with opportunities for technology commercialization, licensing and entrepreneurship.

title: The corporation as agent of cultural fusion
description: Large global corporations don't just impact the local economies of emerging markets, they also play a part in the evolution of their modernizing cultures. Makiko Eda explores how employees balance both global and local cultural norms, showing how the influence goes both ways to create a valuable, more nuanced worldview.
keywords: economics, markets, culture
speaker: Makiko Eda
speaker_about: With the mission of making Intel a truly global organization and creating a career paths for international employees, Makiko Eda continues to push innovative thinking in and out the company. Eda manages all aspects of brand and promotions marketing strategy and execution across Asia Pacific region (excluding Japan and China) for Intel.

title: Weaving a strong smart grid
description: Integrating disparate national electricity systems into a smart grid allows us to integrate renewable energy, be more efficient and empower consumers to use power wisely. But as we add intelligence to these systems, we introduce a vulnerability into it as well. Lorie Wigle outlines a new project to protect these complex and vital grids from attack.
keywords: electricity, energy, engineering
speaker: Lorie Wigle
speaker_about: Lorie Wigle is on a mission to remove the vulnerabilities of the electricity grid. As the general manager of Intel’s eco-technology office, Wigle focuses on the positive environmental impact of Intel’s products. Her work on new business opportunities from use of Intel technologies to address environmental challenges led to the effort on smart grid. She works with policymakers while also playing leadership roles in the Climate Savers Computing Initiative and The Green Grid.

title: Chips, conflict and the Congo
description: The complexities of global geopolitics and the fluid nature of the world's supply chains pose challenges for corporations who want to do the right thing. Gary Niekerk shares the story of how Intel approached the challenge of unraveling its supply chains from mines in the Congo that were funding human rights abuses.
keywords: mining, technology, Africa
speaker: Gary Niekerk
speaker_about: Gary Niekerk has worked inside of some of the world’s most recognizable technology brands to make sure what they do to produce their products is as admirable as the products themselves. In pursuit of this goal, he works with stakeholders and organizations that corporations have traditionally shunned -- believing that your critics can be a valuable source of inspiration and enlightenment.

title: Strategies for fuel-efficient space travel
description: A manned mission to Mars has long captivated our collective imagination. Perhaps the most significant obstacle to achieving this mission is fueling a craft to and from Mars. Erika Debenedictis offers some compelling theories on how we can make it happen.
keywords: space, Mars, rocket science
speaker: Erika Debenedictis
speaker_about: With an eduation in computing science, Erika Debenedictis mines for ways to make space travel more efficent. Debenedictis became the winner of the Intel Science Talent Search in 2010 for her ingenious research on the Interplanetary Transit network. Her work documents how the network can be used to lower fuel requirements for space missions.

title: Interactive experiences with perceptual computing
description: Computers have gotten a lot smarter and faster, but only now are they gaining the ability to see, hear, and feel, igniting a whole new generation of interactivity between man and machine. Achin Bhomik demonstrates how the technology is advancing.
keywords: computers, technology, machine learning
speaker: Achin Bhowmik
speaker_about: Achin Bhowmik is the director of perceptual computing at Intel, where he leads the development and implementation of natural, intuitive and immersive human-computer interaction technologies and solutions. With over 100 publications, including a book and 25 issued patents, he has taught graduate-level courses on computer vision, image processing and display technology.

title: The dark side of storytelling
description: Suzanne Duncan is a story skeptic. She explains what happens when our protective imagination drives a false narrative. Sometimes, she says, the everyday stories we tell ourselves - and how we think about our role in those stories - can do more harm than good.
keywords: storytelling, society, work
speaker: Suzanne Duncan
speaker_about: Suzanne Duncan is a senior vice president and the global head of research for State Street’s Center for Applied Research. She is passionate about creating and sharing new ideas, and she has won multiple awards for groundbreaking research and delivery.

title: Could Moby Dick prevent the next financial crisis?
description: Suzanne Case, a self-identified "bibliobanker," believes that literature's power to foster empathy can change the future of the finance industry. Case argues that insensitivity to the human condition was a key factor in the 2008 recession and shows how a daily dose of Herman Melville or Charles Dickens could be the remedy.
keywords: finance, economics, business
speaker: Suzanne Case
speaker_about: Suzanne Case is a senior vice president at State Street, managing a global operations team that delivers solutions across a breadth of custody, banking and regulatory disciplines. A champion for inclusion, Case helps remove barriers to professional development through coaching, mentoring and company-wide executive sponsorships. She was recognized with State Street’s 2014 Black Professionals Group “Ambassador for Diversity and Inclusion Award” for outstanding leadership.

title: The future of reading. It's fast
description: Does anyone actually read research reports? Stephen Lawrence found that most research in the finance industry rarely gets a glance beyond the front page. Lawrence has dedicated his career to making research reports more digestible, using a refined mixture of machine learning, big data and good old-fashioned human insight.
keywords: finance, machine learning, data
speaker: Stephen Lawrence
speaker_about: Head of Quantextual Research at State Street Global Exchange, Stephen Lawrence has built his career around helping people understand research quickly and efficiently. At State Street, he oversees the development and execution of research aggregation by blending machine learning and big data with the contextual knowledge of human insight and oversight. His team’s “Idea Lab” helps summarize a wide range of research, including academic and sell-side research.

title: The art of letting go...of the floor
description: Aerial flips seem like a counterintuitive skill for Siawn Ou, whose professional and personal life is based on managing and diminishing risk. Through twists and turns, Ou demonstrates how high risk can also lead to great reward and in the end, may be the best investment.
keywords: investment, business, work
speaker: Siawn Ou
speaker_about: Siawn Ou works on the Fund Services Custody team in State Street Sacramento and is the founder of the group Move Well on Collaborate.

title: Can 0.7% of corporate profits fund the world's biggest problems?
description: The United Nations has set a goal to free the world from hunger, poverty and HIV related deaths. But where does the money come from? Conscious capitalist Sahil Sethi identifies a sector resource-rich enough to make the UN's ambitious goals a reality: the corporate world. By donating .7% of their annual profits to the UN goals, he believes corporations can make a game-changing positive impact on our global community.
keywords: capitalism, business, economics
speaker: Sahil Sethi
speaker_about: Born in India and raised across three continents, Sahil Sethi believes capitalism should be a force for good and business should be done for the betterment of society. He is also passionate about getting charities and social organizations plugged into the enterprise economy to make them more sustainable. He works as a Defined Contribution Investment Strategist at State Street Global Advisors in London, helping clients deliver better defined contribution plans for their members.

title: Women in business: entirely unremarkable
description: Kirsten Hall has a provocative question: is it time to stop celebrating women in business, just for being women in business? Maybe, she suggests, we can wind down the idea of corporate women's groups - and position women in business as the new normal.
keywords: women in business, work, business
speaker: Kirsten Hall
speaker_about: Kirsten Hall is a regulatory project manager within Global Markets at State Street, responsible for driving and implementing regulatory change projects. With an interest in the exercise of both social and economic power, Hall is fascinated by the many ways in which language can shape meaning, drive action and construct identities.

title: In defense of extroverts
description: Katherine Lucas is an extrovert — but to her surprise, her cheerful smiles and warm approach gave others the impression that she was less intelligent and lacked leadership skills. Lucas identifies different types of extroverts and argues that the workplace needs them all.
keywords: leadership, society, work
speaker: Katherine Lucas
speaker_about: Whether you are an introvert or extrovert, diverse personalities are often a company’s biggest asset. But sometimes at work there's a struggle to balance personality with “executive presence.” Katherine Lucas is looking at solutions. Head of Marketing for North America at State Street, Lucas works closely with clients and internal teams to understand their challenges and provide direction for marketing programs.

title: Creating music on the go
description: The music synthesizers that are a DJ's stock in trade were once the size of entire rooms. Now the power to create your own music can be housed in a laptop. In a live demo, James Bickerton shows how music production is not just for pros but for everyday people who want to make the beat drop.
keywords: music, economics, business
speaker: James Bickerton
speaker_about: James Bickerton is a global FX business manager and front-office product designer, working in a close-knit team to deliver trading and sales strategies. He is focused on algorithmic execution for electronic and direct trading risk management and helping to manage the expansion of the European GmbH. Bickerton fuses innovative technologies with front-office trading and sales workflows to bring State Street into the future.

title: A rallying cry for office shorts
description: It's time for men to "Free the Knee" at work. In the scorching days of summer women can wear professional skirts but men are impractically confined to long trousers all year round. By spreading a "Free the Knee" campaign, Chris Vogtherr challenges the notion that shorts are unprofessional.
keywords: activism, fashion, work
speaker: Chris Vogtherr
speaker_about: Self-proclaimed knee activist Chris Vogtherr has begun the new manvolution -- the "Free the Knee" campaign. As a senior relationship manager for SSGA, he seeks to revolutinize the male office attire.

title: Perfectionism holds us back. Here's why
description: If you can't do it perfectly, why do it at all? Recovering perfectionist Charly Haversat challenges our obsession with perfection in our personal lives, workplaces and beyond. Can we fight the crippling fear of failure and the unwillingness to compromise that it creates?
keywords: work, business, society
speaker: Charly Haversat
speaker_about: As a reformed perfectionist and former professional athlete, Charly Haversat began noticing that we spend a lot of our personal and professional lives on being flawless. But her big question is: As we obsess about perfection, are we actually getting anything done? A vice president in Alternative Investment Solutions, she focuses on designing scalable, cost-effective programs that meet both our business needs and our clients’ expectations.

title: B.E.A.T. NYC performs at TED@StateStreet
description: Bridging Education and Art Together (B.E.A.T.) transforms the lives of youth in under-served areas through music, dance and writing programs which include beatboxing, B-boying and B-girling (breakdance), music production and composition, and creative writing.
keywords: music, dance, writing
speaker: B.E.A.T. NYC
speaker_about: Bridging Education and Art Together (B.E.A.T.) transforms the lives of youth in under-served areas through music, dance and writing programs which include beatboxing, B-boying and B-girling (breakdance), music production and composition, and creative writing.

title: What if we traded employees like football players?
description: What would happen if new companies hired, fired, and managed in the same way as football clubs? What if new employers "bought" their new hires, and paid old employers a fee, à la Cristiano Ronaldo? In this short talk, Yusuf contemplates the consequence of playing the old corporate game by new rules.
keywords: work, business, sports
speaker: Yusuf Nurbhai
speaker_about: Yusuf Nurbhai is the Chief Administrative Officer for Global Markets in EMEA, responsible for administrative management and coordination of deliverables to global leaders. His career at State Street ranges from research to foreign exchange.

title: How to give teachers an income they deserve
description: What if the time invested by a teacher in a student's future delivered a dividend down the road? If more than just an apple on their desks, teachers benefited financially from the firms their former scholars were helping thrive, perhaps Apple itself? This talk offers a radical approach to education that celebrates the vital role of teachers in a thriving economy.
keywords: education, economics, teaching
speaker: Todd Gershkowitz
speaker_about: Todd Gershkowitz is the head of Global Total Rewards and Shared Services within Global Human Resources at State Street. He’s previously held senior positions at Citigroup, GE, IBM, UBS and with two consulting firms, and has spent about half of his career living and working internationally in Hong Kong, Singapore, the United Kingdom and Switzerland. His professional experiences have inspired his ideas for innovative ways to incentivize and reward employees.

title: We don't need immigration caps. We need minimums
description: Timothy Graf's experiences moving from America to England sparked some fresh ideas about immigration. Our exacting border policies often ignore the significant benefits delivered by the new perspectives of immigrants, fresh ideas that are vital for future success. He argues that smart countries should be lowering roadblocks and setting both caps and minimums when it comes to immigration.
keywords: immigration, success, policy
speaker: Timothy Graf
speaker_about: Timothy Graf leads State Street’s Global Markets’ Macro Strategy team in Europe. His research focuses on the dynamics and trends in developed world economies and the implications they have for global currency and interest rate markets. Incorporating the views built in this process with insights from the world of behavioural finance, he regularly consults with many of the world’s largest institutional investors.

title: Lost in translation: The joy of a jargon-free world
description: When was the last time you optimized something? Perhaps you've been engaging proactively? Are you strategically evolving a market in real-time? Any idea what any of that means? Thea Knight is on a crusade to kill the jargon that is strangling our conversations. She explains how we can be more "intentional" about our words - so we can start to actually say things again.
keywords: business, language, communication
speaker: Thea Knight
speaker_about: Thea Knight, a member of the State Street Internal Communications team, is out to eliminate jargon from the corporate consciousness and provide techniques we can use to make our conversations more productive. Formerly trained as a reporter, Knight is focused on simplifying the way we speak to each other.

title: Investments in the future: A new approach to foreign aid
description: Poor countries need support in order to advance, but there are limits to how much aid can be gifted. How can developed nations encourage long-term help on a grand scale? Financial economist Paul O'Connell proposes a radical approach: enlist private investors to take on the challenge of high-impact causes in developing countries, such as expanding vaccination access in Nigeria. The dividends will pay out on a global scale.
keywords: business, investment, global development
speaker: Paul O'Connell
speaker_about: Paul O'Connell is president and partner of FDO Partners, LLC, an investment management and research firm currently managing US$2.3 billion. FDO is a joint venture partner with State Street Associates. A native of Ireland, O'Connell has a B.A. from Trinity College, Dublin, and a Ph.D. in Economics from Harvard University. He’s also written and published many articles on global finance and capital allocation topics. And he serves as a director of the GAVI Campaign, which works to expand access to immunization, and chairs its Board.

title: A millennial's proposal for a happy multigenerational workplace
description: The unique challenges of integrating millennials into the workplace have been well explored. But what about the other side of the coin? Gen Y'er Patrice Thompson explores the issue from the Gen Y perspective. She charts the differences between Gen X and Gen Y, and maps out a few ways that organizations can create environments where workers of all ages can collaborate and succeed.
keywords: work, society, success
speaker: Patrice Thompson
speaker_about: Patrice Thompson is a permanent member of the Request for Proposal EMEA team, whose aim is to create effective marketing documents that promote products and services for institutional clients. As a graduate from the London School of Economics with a B.Sc. in Government and Economics, Thompson completed three rotations in the Professional Development Program in Foreign Exchange Sales and Trading, Transition Management, and the Regulatory Reform Project Management Office.

title: Not good with names: Local name customs in a global village
description: When Ma Shwe Sin Win (Cynthia) received a LinkedIn request from her father, she ignored it – because she didn't realize it was from him. Forced into the Western first and last name format, her father's Burmese name transformed into something she didn't even recognize. In this playful talk, Ma Shwe Sin Win reflects on naming practices, and thinks about what happens locally when we enforce norms on a global scale.
keywords: society, work, culture
speaker: Cynthia Ma Shwe Sin Win
speaker_about: Since migrating from Singapore at the age of 10, Ma Shwe Sin Win (Cynthia) has noticed how much names impact on how we interact with one another. From school to boardroom, she has made it a point to reflect on what happens when we enforce norms each day. Win manages relationships of FX Connect and Currenex clients for State Street Global Exchange in South East Asia. She’s also a committee member with the Professional Women’s Network of State Street Singapore.

title: The importance of good conversation – and how to have it
description: The night before the Challenger exploded, NASA had a three-hour conference call with a company that knew the shuttle would fail. Why did NASA not abort the mission? John O'Leary explores what makes for an effective conversation. He lists three myths that can lead to destructive silence, and vital techniques to enable good conversation for groups everywhere.
keywords: communication, society, business
speaker: John O'Leary
speaker_about: John O'Leary thinks that we don’t take our conversations in business seriously. Within his role as director of communications of State Street’s business transformation programs, he seeks to remove the barriers that prevent healthy conversation in business. O’Leary is also co-authour of the 2009 best-selling book, “If We Can Put a Man on the Moon” and his writings have appeared in The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post, among others.

title: The power of imagination: Lessons from Shakespeare
description: Shakespeare boasted an uncanny understanding of human nature. Might the Bard be a helpful workplace consultant with tips on navigating the plot twists and characters taking stage in the modern world? (Want to learn whom you can trust at work? Take a meeting with Othello. Need advice on creative problem solving? Check in with Hamlet.) John Bolton walks us through five lessons from the Bard that still resonate today.
keywords: work, communication, business
speaker: John Bolton
speaker_about: Avid Shakespearean John Bolton manages State Street’s thought leadership global program. In his role, he helps the organization to engage with clients and influencers through insights and stories that are powerful and engaging.

title: The power of self-acceptance
description: Poets and doctors both save lives, just in different ways. World-champion slam poet Harry Baker shares the heartache of forfeiting the path of medicine for a self-guided career in poetry and writing. This talk is an ode to choosing to be different, woven through two poems that sing with universal truth. While he won't help the world by becoming a doctor, as he puts it, poetry is just "a less quantifiable way of saving lives."
keywords: poetry, medicine, writing
speaker: Harry Baker
speaker_about: 2012 World Poetry Slam Champion Harry Baker has travelled the world off the strength of his way with words. He combines the nerdiness of being a math student with the hopefulness of being a human.

title: Selfies and seeing ourselves — one artist's look in the mirror
description: Every day, we're surrounded by images of other people. Highly curated portfolios featuring the best snapshots of lives being lived. How does being bombarded with these images ultimately shape how we see ourselves? Artist Christina Balch wants to change the appearance we choose to celebrate, by taking a selfie every day at the ugliest possible time...morning.
keywords: social media, society, technology
speaker: Christina Balch
speaker_about: Christina Balch is a multimedia artist inspired by feminism, technology and human perceptions. Trained in drawing and painting, her interests have shifted to commonly used technologies like smart phones and social media as new tools for creating art. Balch works as an interactive producer, managing mobile and interactive digital products.

title: What I learned from 32 grueling interviews
description: What's less fun than a job interview? Doing it again. And again. And again. Ashwini endured 32 interviews before she landed a job and kept notes on every experience and lesson along the way. Ranging from funny to unbelievable, she shares what she learned (lesson #3: don't wear green) and shows what it's like to search for work as an aspiring businesswoman in India.
keywords: women in business, work, interview
speaker: Ashwini Mrinal Bhagat
speaker_about: Ashwini Mrinal Bhagat is a part of the Global Human Resources team for State Street India, specialising in talent management and employee relations. She believes in creating new platforms for learning and is passionate about employee engagement. She’s also an ardent writer and contributes to daily newspapers and blogs on topics related to current affairs and human resources.

title: Restoring hope and dignity to the justice system
description: You can learn a lot about the character of a country by its jails. Alexander McLean tells of the subhuman treatment he witnessed in African prisons—conditions so brutal that he founded a distance-learning organization that empowers prisoners to fight for their own rights. But the larger question he asks relates not just to Africa: "If as a society we say that someone who has stolen will always be a thief, what skills and gifts and talents do we miss out on?"
keywords: prison, Africa, society
speaker: Alexander McLean
speaker_about: Alexander McLean studied law at Nottingham University and went on to do an LLM with the University of London. He was called to the Bar in 2010 as a Lord Mansfield and Hardwicke Scholar at Lincoln’s Inn, London. McLean founded the African Prisons Project, which develops education programmes in prisons in Africa.

title: My ghost town road trip
description: Explorer and artist Abbey Williams has focused her lens on an eclectic collection of ghost towns that litter the American landscape. With a portfolio of haunting images, Williams contemplates the transitory nature of the places we inhabit, ultimately asking: what do these abandoned cityscapes reveal to us about our modern cities and towns?
keywords: cities, exploration, art
speaker: Abbey Williams
speaker_about: No one knows a good ghost town than Abbey Williams. As those once bustling towns continue to litter the American landscape with its skeletal-like structures, Williams can’t help but wonder what’s to become of our habitats. After interning at State Street Global Advisors for two summers, Williams returned to provide administrative support to the Institutional Client Group’s Mid-Atlantic Relationship Management team.

title: Economics and art
description: What lessons can economics learn from art? Megan Wilkens examines how, historically, trends in the art world have offered a prescient window into wide-ranging socio-economic shifts in society. If economists look closely at art, they might be privy to unexpected changes in cultural behavior.
keywords: economics, art, society
speaker: Megan Wilkens
speaker_about: Megan Wilkens is a graduate from Providence College and the London School of Economics with an education in economics and art history. As an associate at State Street, Wilkens seeks to prove the connection economics and art and find creatively efficient, elegant and analytical solutions.

title: Democratizing investing
description: In 2013, the largest experiment in crowd-sourced investing happened in Australia, as everyday citizens took the reins on investing the country's pension fund. Nathan Ide explores how certain cultural characteristics of Australians have inspired this groundbreaking model for managing pensions.
keywords: crowdsourcing, investment, finance
speaker: Nathan Ide
speaker_about: Nathan Ide is an intermediary sales manager who is passionate about empowered investing and is known for his ability to inspire all investors to take an active interest in investing. At SPDR ETFs Australia, he is responsible for sales and business development to private banks, stock brokers and independent financial advisors. Having studied economics, finance and philosophy, Ide has a Bachelor of Commerce from the University of Sydney.

title: Bring out your inner filmmaker
description: Video is ubiquitous. Companies use it for entertainment, marketing, training – and customers generally expect it. Mark Halliday describes "Studio in a Box," a program he put together which allows State Street employees to make professional-quality videos of their own.
keywords: productivity, technology, film
speaker: Mark Halliday
speaker_about: As director of multimedia experience in the SSgA Global Product and Marketing group, Mark Halliday is responsible for SSgA’s video marketing efforts, from production to technology. With experiences that inform his passion for innovative story telling with digital video, Halliday also works as a surveillance cinematographer in New York City, while writing and directing a feature film and coding movies at the MIT Media Lab that edit themselves on-the-fly.

title: The upside of data
description: Jessica Donohue examines what she's learned from her career working with data, how old industry lessons still apply as we enter the era of Big Data, and why passion still (and always) matters when it comes to data analysis.
keywords: data, technology, finance
speaker: Jessica Donohue
speaker_about: Jessica Donohue directs an innovative partnership that unites financial theory and practice as a senior vice president and head of the research and advisory business at State Street Global Exchange. She and her team capitalize on their exclusive blend of academic and industry knowledge to provide solutions that enhance returns, control risk, optimize performance, manage liquidity, and monitor market conditions. Donohue’s published research on investor behavior provides the foundation for some of State Street’s proprietary indicators.

title: Crowd-sourced investing
description: Making the case for collective intelligence, Hu Liang offers a case study of an investment program that incorporated social media crowd-sourcing and produced dramatically improved performance over typical trading systems.
keywords: crowdsourcing, investment, business
speaker: Hu Liang
speaker_about: Hu Liang is responsible for all business and product strategies and management of the State Street Global Exchange business in Asia Pacific, which focuses on delivering front office data, analytics and trading solutions. Prior to joining State Street through the Currenex acquisition, he was a consultant and researcher. He founded a technology startup in Silicon Valley at the epicenter of the social revolution.

title: Cultural clashes in defining beauty
description: Delali Bright shares her personal story of how growing up in West Africa, she was bullied and marginalized for being skinny. Her family worried about her, put her on diets, and found her embarrassing and shameful. Then, she moved to the U.S. in her 30s, where she was suddenly seen as beautiful! Through her story, Delali illuminates the importance of creating your own self image.
keywords: culture, women in business, beauty
speaker: Delali Bright
speaker_about: Delali Bright is a fund accountant at State Street. Her research focuses on how leadership styles play an important role in political upheaval. She graduated from California State University, Chico with a double major in project management and accounting. Bright is also a certified SAP associate and led a project to convert SAP ERP Financial case studies from IDES to GBI dataset, to support SAP curriculum progress at her university.

title: Making a difference in the world
description: Alison Quirk tells the personal story of taking in a teenager from Nigeria who was recruited to play basketball at her daughter's high school. Through midnight phone calls, hospital visits, and important milestones, Alison explores the wonderful messiness of families – and how to leave a mark on the world.
keywords: Africa, youth, family
speaker: Alison Quirk
speaker_about: Alison Quirk is State Street’s chief human resources and citizenship officer. She is the driving force in the development of State Street’s culture -- ensuring that employees globally feel engaged, valued and committed to its markets and clients. Quirk presents on topics related to career management, inclusion and diversity, and talent management, and she is a frequent contributor to The Huffington Post.

title: You are fluent in this language (and don't even know it)
description: Without realizing it, we're fluent in the language of pictures, says illustrator Christoph Niemann. In a charming talk packed with witty, whimsical drawings, Niemann takes us on a hilarious visual tour that shows how artists tap into our emotions and minds — all without words.
keywords: art, creativity, design, culture, empathy, humor, beauty, communication, humanity
lang: en | tr | nl | pt | fa | lt | fr | hi | ro | ar | hu | pt-BR | he | ru | es | it | zh-Hant | zh-Hans | ko | sr | sv | de | ja | gl | pl | my
speaker: Christoph Niemann
speaker_about: With charm and incisive wit, Christoph Niemann sketches the moments of our shared experience.

title: You may be accidentally investing in cigarette companies
description: Tobacco causes more than seven million deaths every year — and many of us are far more complicit in the problem than we realize. In a bold talk, oncologist Dr. Bronwyn King tells the story of how she uncovered the deep ties between the tobacco industry and the entire global finance sector, which invests our money in cigarette companies through big banks, insurers and pension funds. Learn how Dr. King has ignited a worldwide movement to create tobacco-free investments and how each of us can play a role in ending this epidemic.
keywords: health, finance, investment, global issues, cancer, economics, money, health care, public health, social change, TEDx
lang: en | zh-Hans | zh-Hant | es | pt-BR | sw | ru | tr | fr | pt
speaker: Bronwyn King
speaker_about: Dr. Bronwyn King on a mission to save a billion lives -- from tobacco, the greatest preventable cause of premature death.

title: The breathtaking courage of Harriet Tubman
description: Escaping slavery; risking everything to save her family; leading a military raid; championing the cause of women's suffrage; these are just a handful of the accomplishments of one of America's most courageous heroes. Janell Hobson details Harriet Tubman's many fights for freedom. [TED-Ed Animation by Yan Dan Wong]
keywords: TED-Ed, Slavery, women
lang: en | fa | zh-Hant | es | fr | pt | hr | ko | sl | pt-BR | sr | vi | ar | tr | ja | ru
speaker: Janell Hobson

title: Fake videos of real people — and how to spot them
description: Do you think you're good at spotting fake videos, where famous people say things they've never said in real life? See how they're made in this astonishing talk and tech demo. Computer scientist Supasorn Suwajanakorn shows how, as a grad student, he used AI and 3D modeling to create photorealistic fake videos of people synced to audio. Learn more about both the ethical implications and the creative possibilities of this tech — and the steps being taken to fight against its misuse.
keywords: AI, machine learning, technology, invention, future, media, politics, history, software, computers
lang: en | pt-BR | zh-Hant | tr | th | ja | my | ar | mr | ko | fa | nl | zh-Hans | es | ro | hu | it | pt | el | fr | hy | ru | lt | sq
speaker: Supasorn Suwajanakorn
speaker_about: Supasorn Suwajanakorn works on ways to reconstruct, preserve and reanimate anyone -- just from their existing photos and videos.

title: How to stop swiping and find your person on dating apps
description: Let's face it, online dating can suck. So many potential people, so much time wasted — is it even worth it? Podcaster and entrepreneur Christina Wallace thinks so, if you do it right. In a funny, practical talk, Wallace shares how she used her MBA skill set to invent a "zero date" approach and get off swipe-based apps — and how you can, too.
keywords: love, relationships, life, personal growth, identity
lang: en | pt | tr | hu | fa | my | fr | es | zh-Hans | he | pt-BR | ar | th | ru | zh-Hant | vi | sr | ko | ja | id
speaker: Christina Wallace
speaker_about: A self-described "human Venn diagram," Christina Wallace has crafted a career at the intersection of business, the arts and technology.

title: Home is where the art is
description: Artist Ian Strange turns decrepit suburban homes into art. Using paint and chainsaws, photography and film, he interrogates our concept of home and the narratives we build around it. In this talk, Strange discusses the creative and personal impulses behind his work, and invites us to challenge our own relationships with the places we call home.
keywords: art, community, design, photography, architecture
speaker: Ian Strange
speaker_about: Ian Strange's photographs and videos challenge the idea of the family home as a place of warmth and safety, by simultaneously elevating and destroying it both literally and figuratively. This multidisciplinary artist's work explores photography, sculpture, installation, site-specific intervention, film, documentary work and exhibition, alongside broader themes of disenfranchisement within the urban environment.

title: How AI is making it easier to diagnose disease
description: Today's AI algorithms require tens of thousands of expensive medical images to detect a patient's disease. What if we could drastically reduce the amount of data needed to train an AI, making diagnoses low-cost and more effective? TED Fellow Pratik Shah is working on a clever system to do just that. Using an unorthodox AI approach, Shah has developed a technology that requires as few as 50 images to develop a working algorithm — and can even use photos taken on doctors' cell phones to provide a diagnosis. Learn more about how this new way to analyze medical information could lead to earlier detection of life-threatening illnesses and bring AI-assisted diagnosis to more health care settings worldwide.
keywords: medicine, TED Fellows, AI, technology, medical imaging, future, cancer, health care, innovation, illness, machine learning, science, medical research, health
lang: en | fa | pt-BR | zh-Hans | my | fr | zh-Hant | ro | gl | ar | he | ko | es | pt | ru | tr | hu | cs | ku
speaker: Pratik Shah
speaker_about: Dr. Pratik Shah creates novel intersections between engineering, medical imaging, machine learning and medicine.

title: Why doctors are offering free tax prep in their waiting rooms
description: More than 90 percent of children in the US see a doctor at least once a year, which means countless hours spent in waiting rooms for parents. What if those hours could be used for something productive — like saving money? Through her organization StreetCred, pediatrician and TED Fellow Lucy Marcil is offering free tax prep to parents right in the waiting room, reimagining what a doctor's visit can look like and helping to lift families out of poverty. Learn more about how free tax prep and guidance could be the best poverty prescription we have in the US.
keywords: TED Fellows, medicine, health care, children, finance, social change, family, parenting, health
lang: en | pt-BR | fa | my | es | sq | pt | ru | zh-Hans | zh-Hant | pl | ja | tr | it | th | he | ar | hu | vi | ta | ko | fr
speaker: Lucy Marcil
speaker_about: Lucy Marcil is providing fiscal services to low-income families in the doctor’s waiting room.

title: How to train employees to have difficult conversations
description: It's time to invest in face-to-face training that empowers employees to have difficult conversations, says Tamekia MizLadi Smith. In a witty, provocative talk, Smith shares a workplace training program called "I'm G.R.A.C.E.D." that will inspire bosses and employees alike to communicate with compassion and respect. Bottom line: always let people know why their work matters.
keywords: communication, compassion, identity, data, race, teaching, social change, work
lang: en | es | he | fr | zh-Hant | pt-BR | ru | de | ko | ar | pt | zh-Hans | nl | sl | tr | fa
speaker: Tamekia MizLadi Smith
speaker_about: Tamekia MizLadi Smith wants to start new conversations around involving non-clinical staff in healthcare.

title: "Dead Romance"
description: Acoustic duo Anielle Reid and Matthew Brookshire (playing together as Boy Girl Banjo) take the TED stage to perform their original song "Dead Romance," weaving together the sounds of Americana folk music and modern pop.
keywords: music, live music, guitar, performance art, performance, vocals
lang: en | fa | es | my | pt-BR | ro | sw | ar | hi | zh-Hans | el | tr | it | de | ru | zh-Hant | fr | th | ko | pt | ta | nl | sk
speaker: Boy Girl Banjo
speaker_about: Anielle Reid is an American singer-songwriter and banjoist.

title: How abstract mathematics can help us understand the world
description: Most people think of pure mathematics as a medium for ivory-tower abstraction, divorced from real-world applications. Mathematician Eugenia Cheng disagrees. In this talk, she demonstrates how numbers and mathematical structures can be used to shift perspectives, switch contexts and help us understand our fellow human beings in new and logical ways.
keywords: Science (hard), empathy, education, inclusion, society
speaker: Eugenia Cheng
speaker_job: Mathematician, concert pianist and scientist in residence
speaker_about: Dr Eugenia Cheng is a mathematician and concert pianist. She is Scientist in Residence at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and won tenure at the University of Sheffield, UK, where she is now Honorary Fellow. She has a PhD in pure mathematics from the University of Cambridge. Alongside her research in Category Theory and undergraduate teaching her aim is to rid the world of ‘maths phobia’. Eugenia was an early pioneer of mathematics on YouTube and her videos have been viewed over 10 million times. Her first popular maths book, How to Bake Pi, was featured on the Late Show with Stephen Colbert, and Beyond Infinity was shortlisted for the Royal Society Science Book Prize 2017. She writes the Everyday Math column for the Wall Street Journal, and recently completely her first mathematical art commission. Her next book, The Art of Logic, is out in 2018.

title: A day in the life of an ancient Egyptian doctor
description: It's another sweltering morning in Memphis, Egypt. As the sunlight brightens the Nile, Peseshet checks her supplies. Honey, garlic, cumin, acacia leaves, cedar oil — she's well stocked with the essentials she needs to treat her patients. Elizabeth Cox outlines a day in the life of an ancient Egyptian doctor. [TED-Ed Animation by Echo Bridge]
keywords: TED-Ed, medicine, ancient world, storytelling, history, disease
lang: en | fr | es | pt | fa | zh-Hans | ar | tr | vi | hr | zh-Hant | hu | pt-BR | sl | pl | sq | ru | ko | sr | el | th | ro
speaker: Elizabeth Cox

title: Where are all the aliens?
description: The universe is incredibly old, astoundingly vast and populated by trillions of planets — so where are all the aliens? Astronomer Stephen Webb has an explanation: we're alone in the universe. In a mind-expanding talk, he spells out the remarkable barriers a planet would need to clear in order to host an extraterrestrial civilization — and makes a case for the beauty of our potential cosmic loneliness. "The silence of the universe is shouting, 'We're the creatures who got lucky,'" Webb says.
keywords: astronomy, cosmos, universe, science, space, physics, time, exploration, Planets
lang: en | tr | he | zh-Hant | sr | pt | es | fr | nl | pt-BR | it | ko | hu | zh-Hans | ru | de | el | sl
speaker: Stephen Webb
speaker_about: Stephen Webb is a science fiction fan who's passionately interested in what the future might hold for our species.

title: El impacto del marketing en los medicamentos que tomamos
description: ¿Cómo impacta el marketing en los medicamentos que nos receta nuestro médico? Pablo Santa Cruz describe los incentivos muchas veces inconcientes de los doctores y nos sugiere cómo conversar con nuestros médicos para mejorar el cuidado de nuestra salud.​
keywords: TED en Español
speaker: Pablo Santa Cruz
speaker_about: Pablo Santa Cruz, Médico Cirujano de la Universidad de Los Andes y Psiquiatra del Instituto Psiquiátrico Dr. José Horwitz Barak, es co-fundador de Médicos Sin Marca, ONG que busca promover un ejercicio clínico responsable, basado en evidencia y libre de las influencias de la propaganda y los incentivos provenientes de la industria farmacéutica, de dispositivos médicos y de alimentos, con el fin de entregar una atención transparente e independiente a los pacientes.

title: Fracaso tras fracaso
description: La forma en que manejamos la adversidad en nuestras vidas tiene un fuerte impacto en qué podemos lograr y cómo vivimos el camino. Karla Souza, actriz mexicana, comparte su filosofía del manejo de la adversidad y algunas historias que le contaba su padre.
keywords: TED en Español, family, storytelling, life
speaker: Karla Souza
speaker_about: Una de las mexicanas más creativas del mundo según Forbes Magazine, Karla es actriz de carácter global, convencida de que son las historias las que cautivan al espectador. Fue la Actriz Revelación del Año y ganó el Premio Canacine como Mejor Actriz por su interpretación de Babi Noble en la película mexicana “Nosotros los Nobles”. Actualmente trabaja en la serie norteamericana “How to get away with murder”.

title: Reescribe el cuento de tu vida
description: Desde chiquitos, todos escribimos un cuento: nuestro cuento, el cuento de nuestra vida. Lucas Raspall, médico psiquiatra, nos invita a cuestionar y reescribir nuestros propios cuentos.
keywords: TED en Español, self, mental health, storytelling, psychology
speaker: Lucas Raspall
speaker_about: A veces es médico, otras veces psiquiatra. Muchas veces es psicoterapeuta o acupuntor. Con mucho descaro es músico, pintor y, por qué no, escritor. Es estudiante, profesor universitario y de posgrados, conferencista y divulgador. Es un espectador privilegiado de su propia mente e investigador incansable de sus laberintos. Es experto en nada y confeso principiante en todo. Es hijo, hermano y padre, por esto, es niño y adulto. Es marido de la mujer que ama y novio eterno de la vida. En definitiva, es una persona: nada más.

title: La verdad es mentira
description: Después de recorrer el camino en búsqueda de nuestra identidad y encontrarla, nos podemos dar cuenta de que se transforma en una prisión. Daniel Molina nos muestra con humor e ironía cómo la interpretación que hacemos de la realidad moldea nuestro mundo interno y toda la sociedad.
keywords: TED en Español, identity, self, society
speaker: Daniel Molina
speaker_about: Allí donde se mezclan las nuevas tendencias, el arte, la literatura, la vida cotidiana y la sociedad, está Dani, con sus escritos, sus artículos sobre cultura, sus programas de tele. Pasó por todos lados: El Porteño, Crisis, Fin de Siglo, Página/12, El Cronista, Clarín, La Nación, Perfil… y siguen las columnas. Desde el Centro Cultural Ricardo Rojas (UBA) nos viene abriendo la cabeza desde hace años. Charlar con Dani, o asistir a sus cursos, es un viaje que nunca sabemos dónde nos lleva.

title: La importancia de la improvisación
description: "Como educadores, tenemos el deber de soñar y crear espacios donde todo el mundo tenga la oportunidad de sacar lo mejor de sí mismo." Por eso a Juan López-Aranguren le encanta la basura; después de todo, la basura de un hombre puede ser la inspiración de otro. En esta divertida charla, López-Aranguren comparte cuentos de construcción improvisada e instalaciones de arte espontáneas, todo montado con el fin de encender la chispa de la creatividad.
keywords: TED en Español, education, creativity, design, art
speaker: Juan López-Aranguren
speaker_about: Educador. Juan López-Aranguren se licenció en arquitectura por la Escuela Técnica Superior de Madrid, aunque tardó 14 años en acabar la carrera. Esos 14 años, asegura haberlos invertido bien. Ha recorrido el mundo con amigos llevando a cabo proyectos de difícil catalogación y que han sido objeto de estudio desde ámbitos tan dispares como la arquitectura o la antropología y que cuentan entre sus socios a instituciones como el colegio IDEO, la asociación de vecinos de Villaverde Alto, el CSIC, el Ministerio de Medioambiente y el Guggenheim de Nueva york. El resultado de esta prolífica década se conoce como Basurama. Organización de la que Juan es miembro fundador. Desde ella ha liderado programas como Autobarrios, Imaginar Patio, Residuos Urbanos Sólidos o In love We Trash, premiados y publicados tanto a nivel nacional como internacional.

title: Humanizar los cuidados intensivos
description: Las unidades de cuidados intensivos (UCI) de los hospitales salvan muchas vidas. Pero ¿cuál es la secuela emocional en los pacientes? Gabriel Heras describe el dolor emocional de los pacientes y de sus personas cercanas al pasar por la UCI y describe su proyecto para humanizar los cuidados intensivos.
keywords: TED en Español, health, health care, emotions, medicine
speaker: Gabriel Heras
speaker_about: Gabriel es médico especialista en Medicina Intensiva y el creador e impulsor del proyecto HU-CI, Humanizando los cuidados intensivos, una nueva forma de entender el cuidado de los pacientes críticos que está transformando la Sanidad. Recibió el año pasado el Premio por esta iniciativa a la Mejor Idea de la Sanidad 2014 en la Iniciativa Legal, Ética y Deontológica, organizado por el periódico especializado Diario Médico. Además con su necesidad de compartir y crear colectivamente, unido a su vertiente bloguera, pone en marcha el blog www.humanizandoloscuidadosintensivos.com, creando en muy poco tiempo un espacio abierto y punto de encuentro para todos los profesionales, pacientes y familiares comprometidos con esta tarea y se convierte en un megáfono de esa nueva aproximación.

title: Las palabras de la discriminación
description: Carmen Jiménez Borja muestra cómo las palabras que usamos pueden ser la causa de mucha discriminación y prejuicios y comparte las acciones que está llevando a cabo, como mujer gitana, para luchar contra los muros de rechazo. ​
keywords: TED en Español, language, education
speaker: Carmen Jiménez Borja
speaker_about: Comprometida con la igualdad de oportunidad y las posibilidades que el Derecho ofrece para que esta sea efectiva, Carmen trabaja en la Fundación Secretariado Gitano como técnica de igualdad, para lograr que mujeres de etnia gitana, como ella, puedan lograr el empoderamiento y luchar contra las desigualdades de género que existen dentro y fuera de su comunidad. Alta sensibilidad hacia las problemáticas sociales, destacando las situaciones de discriminación y derecho a la igualdad de trato. Actualmente, estudia el master de Acceso a la abogacía en la Universidad de Valladolid para defender ante los tribunales las injusticias discriminatorias existentes en la sociedad. Se muestra como una soñadora incansable, lucha en su día a día por promover una sociedad inclusiva e intercultural. Su mejor arma: su propia experiencia y trayectoria, capaz de contrarrestar los estereotipos negativos a los que su comunidad se enfrenta. Y su voz, un misil de motivación para otras mujeres gitanas que deseen seguir su camino.

title: Nuestras mentiras en la vida y en los negocios
description: Néstor Guerra comparte las mentiras que solemos hacernos a nosotros mismos a la hora de emprender un nuevo negocio y describe tres de los principales sesgos que nos llevan al fracaso. Sin embargo también argumenta que muchas veces las mentiras son necesarias en la vida
keywords: TED en Español, trust, entrepreneur, business, work
speaker: Néstor Guerra
speaker_about: Actualmente es CEO y cofundador de IEC, startup dedicada al desarrollo de soluciones para smart cities. Compatibiliza esta función con la de profesor de Business Design & Lean Startup en la Escuela de Organización Industrial EOI en Postgrados, MBAs y in-Company. También es Profesor de Innovación y Lean Startup a h2i Institute.

title: ¿A quién pertenece el pasado?
description: ¿Qué es lo que podemos poseer del pasado? ¿El tiempo, la memoria, los objetos? Alberto Garín explora cómo nos apropiamos del pasado y se pregunta qué significa que declaremos algo (ya sea el garaje de Steve Jobs o las pirámides de Tikal) patrimonio histórico nacional.
keywords: TED en Español, history, education, teaching
speaker: Alberto Garín
speaker_about: Alberto Garin (PhD) es historiador por la École de Hautes Études en Sciences Sociales de París y director del programa Exploraciones sobre la Historia y profesor en la Universidad Francisco Marroquín.

title: La voz del artista
description: ¿Cuál es la responsabilidad social de los artistas? Fernanda Castillo, actriz mexicana, describe su camino para descubrir su papel social y el impacto que tiene en la gente que la sigue.​
keywords: TED en Español, art, arts, design, social change
speaker: Fernanda Castillo
speaker_about: Fernanda es actriz de Teatro, Cine y Televisión. Entre sus trabajos más destacados está su papel protagónico en la obra de teatro musical 'Hoy no me puedo levantar' y su interpretación de Mónica Robles en la serie de televisión 'El Señor de los Cielos'. Ha dirigido y producido teatro. Recientemente produjo y protagonizó la puesta en escena 'Wake Up Woman' en México en la que aborda el tema de la violencia de género y en pareja.

title: What the Russian Revolution would have looked like on social media
description: History is written by the victors, as the saying goes — but what would it look like if it was written by everyone? Journalist and TED Fellow Mikhail Zygar is on a mission to show us with Project1917, a "social network for dead people" that posts the real diaries and letters of more than 3,000 people who lived during the Russian Revolution. By showing the daily thoughts of the likes of Lenin, Trotsky and many less celebrated figures, the project sheds new light on history as it once was — and as it could have been. Learn more about this digital retelling of the past as well as Zygar's latest project about the transformative year of 1968.
keywords: social media, politics, history, Internet, journalism, technology, TED Fellows

speaker: Mikhail Zygar

title: Duelo por la muerte del padre
description: Hernán Casciari hace el duelo por la muerte de su padre en vivo en esta charla.
keywords: TED en Español, self, death, life, emotions
speaker: Hernán Casciari
speaker_about: Hernán escribe libros y novelas. Columnista del programa Todo Pasa en Océano FM. En el año 2000 se radicó en Barcelona. Tuvo un infarto y nació de nuevo en Montevideo, Uruguay, el 6 de diciembre de 2015. A causa del susto, desde 2016 vive en Buenos Aires.

title: Un ejército de mujeres
description: ¿Qué sucede cuando las mujeres toman las armas y forman un ejército para defender sus derechos? La cineasta Alba Sotorra nos presenta a Aryan, una comandante de un ejército de mujeres en el norte de Siria, a quién siguió con su cámara durante la guerra.
keywords: TED en Español, women, photography, global issues, war, gender
speaker: Alba Sotorra
speaker_about: Alba Sotorra, born in Reus in 1980, studied cinema at the Complutense University of Madrid and in the University of Puerto Rico. She directs and produces documentaries. Her work is based on human stories that lead to reflection on subjects such as freedom, equality, and identity, from a gender perspective. Her second documentary “Game over” (2015) was awarded the Gaudí 2016 as the best documentary, and she also received the New Talent award at DocsBarcelona. She is now finishing the shooting and editing of her fourth documentary, which is about Kurdish female guerrilla in Kobané, with whom she has lived in the war front for several months.

title: How I went from child refugee to international model
description: Halima Aden made history when she became the first hijab-wearing model on the cover of Vogue magazine. Now she returns to Kenya's Kakuma Refugee Camp — where she was born and lived until the age of seven — to share an inspiring message about what she's learned on the path from child refugee to international model.
keywords: global issues, fashion, refugees, TEDx, identity, society, community, humanity, culture

speaker: Halima Aden
speaker_about: Halima Aden was the first ever hijab-wearing fashion model.

title: Why I fight for the education of refugee girls (like me)
description: After fleeing war-torn South Sudan as a child, Mary Maker found security and hope in the school at Kenya's Kakuma Refugee Camp. Now a teacher of young refugees herself, she sees education as an essential tool for rebuilding lives — and empowering a generation of girls who are too often denied entrance into the classroom. "For the child of war, an education can turn their tears of loss into a passion for peace," Maker says.
keywords: global issues, refugees, education, teaching, community, children, social change, peace, TEDx
lang: en | lt | my | zh-Hant | sv | es | ar | fr | hu | sl | ro | it | ku | he | hy | pt | pt-BR | tr | fa
speaker: Mary Maker
speaker_about: Mary Maker believes in the power of education to build peace and rebuild lives.

title: What your smart devices know (and share) about you
description: Once your smart devices can talk to you, who else are they talking to? Kashmir Hill and Surya Mattu wanted to find out — so they outfitted Hill's apartment with 18 different internet-connected devices and built a special router to track how often they contacted their servers and see what they were reporting back. The results were surprising — and more than a little bit creepy. Learn more about what the data from your smart devices reveals about your sleep schedule, TV binges and even your tooth-brushing habits — and how tech companies could use it to target and profile you. (This talk contains mature language.)
keywords: technology, surveillance, Internet, society, business, consumerism
lang: en | pt-BR | he | es | tr | sr | it | ru | ar | fr | zh-Hans | zh-Hant | fa | ko | hu | uk | pt | ro | ml | bg | cs | id
speaker: Kashmir Hill and Surya Mattu
speaker_about: Kashmir Hill writes about privacy and technology.

title: History vs. Augustus
description: His reign marked the beginning of one of history's greatest empires ... and the end of one of its first republics. Was Rome's first emperor a visionary leader who guaranteed his civilization's place in history, or a tyrant who destroyed its core values? Peta Greenfield and Alex Gendler put this controversial figure on trial in History vs. Augustus. [TED-Ed Animation by Brett Underhill]
keywords: TED-Ed, history, politics, ancient world, government
lang: en | es | zh-Hant | tr | pt | vi | ar | pl | zh-Hans | hr | pt-BR | sr | nl | fr | ko | ru
speaker: Peta Greenfield & Alex Gendler

title: How memory science can help fight harassment
description: One of the obstacles facing those who have experienced workplace harassment is the scarcity of reporting mechanisms that adequately combine fact-finding rigor with emotional support. Drawing from a decade studying police interviews and the ways trauma interacts with memory, Dr. Julia Shaw discusses how cognitive science and online tools can help survivors record their experiences while prioritizing their well-being.
keywords: technology, science, sexual violence, memory, women, work
speaker: Julia Shaw
speaker_about: Julia Shaw is best known for her work in the areas of memory and criminal psychology.

title: The power of diversity within yourself
description: Rebeca Hwang has spent a lifetime juggling identities — Korean heritage, Argentinian upbringing, education in the United States — and for a long time she had difficulty finding a place in the world to call home. Yet along with these challenges came a pivotal realization: that a diverse background is a distinct advantage in today's globalized world. In this personal talk, Hwang reveals the endless benefits of embracing our complex identities — and shares her hopes for creating a world where identities aren't used to alienate but to bring people together instead.
keywords: identity, diversity, community, family, self, humanity, society, TED en Español, education, children
lang: en | tr | es | my | pt-BR | it | ro | sq | ar | hy | sr | vi | zh-Hant | hu | th | zh-Hans | ko | sl | cs | nl | pt | hi | el | fa | ru | ja
speaker: Rebeca Hwang
speaker_about: Rebeca Hwang is co-founder and managing director of Rivet Ventures, investing in solutions for women and empowering their choices.

title: El valor de nuestra diversidad interna
description: Rebeca Hwang nació en Corea, se crió en Argentina y fue educada en los Estados Unidos. Como alguien que ha vivido identidades cambiantes, Hwang afirma que, aunque a veces sea desafiante, tener una identidad diversa en realidad es una ventaja. En su charla comparte cómo la diversidad interna de sus identidades le permite establecer conexiones con gente de todo tipo y cómo estas diversidades se puedan utilizar para unir a las personas, no para dividirlas.
keywords: TED en Español, identity, self, children, education, humanity, community, society, diversity, family
lang: es | en
speaker: Rebeca Hwang
speaker_about: Rebeca Hwang is co-founder and managing director of Rivet Ventures, investing in solutions for women and empowering their choices.

title: The mission to create a searchable database of Earth's surface
description: What if you could search the surface of the Earth the same way you search the internet? Will Marshall and his team at Planet use the world's largest fleet of satellites to image the entire Earth every day. Now they're moving on to a new project: using AI to index all the objects on the planet over time — which could make ships, trees, houses and everything else on Earth searchable, the same way you search Google. He shares a vision for how this database can become a living record of the immense physical changes happening across the globe. "You can't fix what you can't see," Marshall says. "We want to give people the tools to see change and take action."
keywords: technology, space, photography, environment
